title: Pan South African Language Board
text:
The Pan South African Language Board (, abbreviated PanSALB) is an organization in <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a> established to promote <a href="multilingualism">multilingualism</a>, to develop the <a href="Languages%20of%20South%20Africa">11 official languages</a>, and to protect <a href="Linguistic%20rights">language rights</a> in South Africa. The Board was established in Act 59 of 1995 by the <a href="Parliament%20of%20South%20Africa">Parliament of South Africa</a>.
In addition to the 11 official languages of South Africa, PanSALB also strives for the development of the <a href="Khoe%20languages">Khoe</a>, <a href="Khoisan%20languages">San</a>, and <a href="South%20African%20Sign%20Language">South African Sign Language</a>.
PanSALB structures include: Provincial Language Committees, the National Language Bodies and the National Lexicography Units.
Controversy.
In January 2016, South African <a href="Minister%20of%20Arts%20and%20Culture">Minister of Arts and Culture</a>, <a href="Nathi%20Mthethwa">Nathi Mthethwa</a> dissolved the entire board of PanSALB, after a report that between 2014 and 2015, the board's administrative expenditure had increased from 8 million to 11 million <a href="South%20African%20rand">ZAR</a>, while the expenditure on its mandate dropped to 17 million from 23 million ZAR, while its irregular expenditure was 28 million.
